intro: Hyssopus anethiodorus, commonly known as wild hyssop, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, lance-shaped leaves that have a minty fragrance. Its flowers are small, tubular, and typically purple or blue, arranged in spikes at the ends of the stems. Hyssopus anethiodorus is often found in rocky or limestone soils and is used in traditional medicine for its purported antiseptic and anti-inflammatory properties.
